Represents the network latency, in milliseconds for a user action.

Represents the time spent transferring data for a user action. For page actions the network contribution is calculated by dividing the resource size by the estimated bandwidth. It is assumed that the transferred data is equally distributed using the current bandwidth. For mobile actions the network contribution is calculated by subtracting the server contribution from the overall time the request takes from sending the request, until the response is received.

Page Faults are not errors per se, they occur when data in the virtualized address space is accessed which is not currently present in the physical memory. A high or rising number is an indicator that more memory is actively in use than the machine has physically available.

measure.id: SUD High GC Activity - CPU Utilization

measure.description: Percentage of garbage collection time related to CPU time of the Java Virtual Machine within the last sample interval (10s). Does not work for IBM JVMs.
measure.id: SUD High GC Activity - GC Utilization

measure.description: Represents the time spent on the server that had an impact on the user action response time. It is calculated by summing up the time each web request spends on the server, whereas overlapping times are counted only once. If the duration of a web request exceeds the user action response time, only the time until the end of the response time is added.
Indicates if the declared Web Request came from a specific user agent within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.
Sql execute time
Suspension time caused by GC per Interval.
Indicates if the declared Web Request was invoked with a specific tagged header field set to a specific value within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.
Processes currently requiring CPU time. If this number is larger than 1 the system is overloaded.

actiongroupconfig.actiongroup_description: This default group matches all user actions that caused the web browser to navigate to a new page.
This default group matches all user actions that caused an XMLHttpRequest.
This default group matches all user actions that were created using the Javascript ADK.
This default group lets you configure a separate threshold for your app starts.
This default group matches all automatically created mobile actions.
This default group matches all user actions that were created using the Mobile ADK.

module.hint: Support for ExtJS framework (featurehash='e').
Enables instrumentation of the prototype framework (featurehash='o').
Module for capturing timed actions (featurehash='t').
JS agent thirdparty content detection module.
module.description: JS agent thirdparty content detection module(featurehash='3').

module.hint: Module for capturing WebSocket Communication (featurehash='w')
JS agent module for Ajax (XHR) detection (featurehash='x')
Enables support to integrate manually-added Gomez page ID's and group ID's into dynaTrace. (featurehash=z)
JS agent thirdparty content detection module.
Enables capturing of actions
JS agent mooTools for Ajax (XHR) detection (featurehas='m').
Enables instrumentation of the AngularJS framework (featurehash='g').
Template for generated system profile configs and automatic injection of js agent.
JS agent fixes execScript problem module(featurehash='1').
Enables instrumentation of the ICEfaces framework (featurehash='i').
Enables capturing of JS errors.
Enables capturing of measures for audio/video tags.
JS agent bandwidth check module.(featurehash='b').
JS agent resource timing module.
Enables capturing of perceived render time
JS agent module for Ajax (XHR) detection for older Internet Explorer browsers (featurehash='v').
Enables instrumentation of the jquery framework (featurehash='j').
Enables wrapping of the addEventListenerWrapper.
Enables instrumentation of the dojo framework (featurehash='d').

incidentrule.description: Saves 5 minutes before+after of the buffer if a PurePaths takes over 30 seconds.
Saves 5 minutes before+after of the buffer if a PurePaths contains exceptions.
A prior connected Application Process/Agent was shut down.
Connection to a previously connected Application Process/Agent has been lost.
Raises incidents for individual connected agents.
Session was cleared.
The system profile configuration changed.

Agent automatically disabled its instrumentation. Possible reasons are for example, if there was no Collector reachable when the Agent was started up or overall instrumentation performance on the Collector was too low.
Creates an incident when high cpu usage is detected for a longer period.
incidentrule.id: High CPU Usage for Application Process

condition.refmeasure: High CPU Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.description: Fires an incident when a high amount of process time is used for garbage collection.
incidentrule.id: High GC Activity for Application Process

condition.refmeasure: SUD High GC Activity - CPU Utilization
SUD High GC Activity - GC Utilization

incidentrule.description: Memory usage sustained at a high percentage for a longer time period.
incidentrule.id: High Memory Usage for Application Process

condition.refmeasure: High Memory Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.description: Agent disabled CPU time capturing because of too high overhead. Check the agent's CPU time capturing options in the agent group's sensor configuration dialog.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that are corrupted.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have been truncated as their size exceeds the node limit.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have timed out as either a method has not returned, or a whole child path did not finish within a certain timeout.
Signals performed agent hot sensor placement
Application Process reported Out-of-memory. A Memory Dump will be automatically triggered if not disabled in the Agent group settings.
Continuous transaction recording was aborted.
A test violation (test has degraded/improved/failed, or is volatile) occurred.
Custom user created Incidents.
The overall failed transaction rate exceeds the configured threshold.
The overall failed page action rate exceeds the configured threshold.
incidentrule.id: High Overall Failed Page Action Rate

incidentrule.description: The average response time (median) is significantly higher than expected. Although the observed response time might be still acceptable for users, this behavior is typically caused by application or infrastructure problems and reduces the maximum throughput you can achieve.
The observed response time for the slowest 10% of requests has increased significantly. This results in poor user experience and can be caused by application or infrastructure problems.
incidentrule.id: Response time degraded for slow requests

incidentrule.description: The rate of failed transactions is significantly higher than expected.
Orderly shutdown of Application Process/Agent.
Custom user created incidents for deployment.
The process thresholds of the host are violated.
Agent lost connection to database
Database Agent does not have privileges to work correctly
Agent connected to unsupported database version. Unpredictable events may occur
Potentially stuck Java VM. It's neither due to a heap/thread dump or GC activity. The reason is unknown and requires manual investigation.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk (Host)

measure.description: Tracks the number of message references in the instance state queue for this particular host.
measure.metricid: Host Queue - Instance State Msg Refs - Length
measure.id: Host Queue - Instance State Msg Refs - Length

item.value: Host Queue - Instance State Msg Refs - Length

measure.description: Tracks the total number of messages in the particular host queue.
Tracks the number of instances of this particular host.
Tracks the total number of suspended messages for the particular host.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk, all counters are stored in seperate instances that is called the same name as the BizTalk Hosting Process so the normal Windows Counters can't pull the data out. Eg. default instance is BizTalkServerApplication and is hosted by BTSNTSvc.exe, so {pid} and {monitored_process} doesn't work propperly.

measure.description: Number of receive locations currently enabled in this host instance.

Number of threads in the Messaging Engine currently processing messages received from adapters running in this host instance. These include messages that have been processed asynchronously by send adapters.
Number of messages the Messaging Engine has currently in send processing. This includes messages currently in send pipeline processing as well as response messages for receive adapters.
Number of threads in the Messaging Engine currently processing messages to send to adapters. This includes response messages to receive adapters.
Documents processed
Documents processed/Sec
Documents received
Documents received/Sec
Total number of documents resubmitted by send adapters.
Documents submitted/Batch
Documents suspended
Documents suspended/Sec
Documents transmitted/Batch
Number of messages given by the Messaging Engine to send adapters that have not completed processing. This includes response messages for receive adapters.
Number of request messages that have not received a response message within the time limit specified by the adapter.

Number of messages in the database queues that this process has published. This value is measured by the number of items in the queue tables for all hosts and the number of items in the spool and tracking tables. If a process is publishing to multiple queues, this counter reflects the weighted average of all the queues.
The number of currently opened database sessions exceeds the BizTalk threshold.

The destination queue depth of all messagebox databases exceeds the BizTalk threshold. If the host publishes to multiple queues, the weighted average across all destination queues is computed (based on recent publish statistics) and compared with the BizTalk threshold.
The number of in-process messages exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The message delivery rate is higher than the message processing rate.
The message publishing request rate is higher than the message publishing completion rate.
The process memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The system-wide physical memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The thread count exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
Number of bytes received by adapter
Number of bytes received by adapter per second.
Number of times file receive adapter failed to lock the file per second.
Number of messages received by adapter
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of bytes sent by adapter per second.
Number of bytes sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Number of loaded orchestration application domains in the process.
Number of persistence points reached since the host instance started, divided by the number of underlying transactions.
Number of database transactions performed since the host instance started.
Average number performed per second.
Number of orchestrations instances that can be dehydrated which are currently hosted by the host instance.
Number of orchestrations that are in the process of dehydrating.
Indicates whether there is a dehydration cycle currently in progress.
Number of dehydration cycles completed.

Number in milliseconds that determines how aggressively orchestrations are being dehydrated. If the orchestration engine predicts that an instance will be dehydratable for an amount of time longer than this threshold, it will dehydrate the instance.

Number of idle orchestration instances currently hosted by the host instance. This refers to orchestrations that are not making progress but are not dehydratable, as when the orchestration is blocked waiting for a receive, listen, or delay in an atomic transaction.
Megabytes of allocated private memory for the host instance.
Megabytes reserved for virtual memory for the host instance.
Number of attempted database connections that failed since the host instance started.
Number of MessageBox databases currently available to the application.
Number of orchestration instances completed since the host instance started.
Average number completed per second.
Number of orchestration instances created since the host instance started.
Average number created per second.
Number of orchestration instances dehydrated since the host instance started.
Average number dehydrated per second.
Number of orchestration instances discarded from memory since the host instance started. An orchestration can be discarded if the engine fails to persist its state.
Average number discarded per second.
Number of orchestration instances rehydrated since the host instance started.
Average number rehydrated per second.
Number of orchestration instances currently hosted by the host instance.
Number of dehydratable orchestrations for which there is a dehydration request pending.
Number of orchestration instances suspended since the host instance started.
Average number suspended per second.
Number of received messages for which receipt has not yet been acknowledged to the message box.
Number of code execution blocks that are scheduled for execution.
Number of times an orchestration instance has persisted its state to the database since the host instance started.
Average number of orchestration instances persisted per second.
Number of orchestration instances ready to execute.
Number of orchestration instances currently executing.
Number of long-running or atomic scopes that have been aborted since the host instance started.
Average number aborted per second.
Number of long-running or atomic scopes that have successfully completed since the host instance started.
Average number committed per second.
Number of long-running or atomic scopes that have successfully completed compensation scopes since the application started.
Average number compensated per second.
Percentage used of total physical memory on the machine.
The delay injected in each qualifying batch for throttling the publishing of messages.
The number of message publish requests issued by the service class per second.
The number of messages actually published by the service class per second.

A flag indicating whether the system is throttling message publishing (affecting XLANG message processing and inbound transports).
* 0: Not throttling * 2: Throttling due to imbalanced message publishing rate (input rate exceeds output rate) * 4: Throttling due to process memory pressure * 5: Throttling due to system memory pressure * 6: Throttling due to database growth * 8: Throttling due to high session count * 9: Throttling due to high thread count * 11: Throttling due to user override on publishing
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message publish throttling.

This counter reflects the user override that is monitored by the engine and interpreted as follows:
* 0: No override * 1: Always throttle message publishing * 2: Do not throttle message publishing
Number of messages received by adapter
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
The delay injected in each batch for throttling the delivery of messages.
The number of messages delivered to the service class per second.
The number of messages processed by the service class per second.
A flag indicating whether the system is throttling message delivery (affecting XLANG message processing and outbound transports).
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message delivery throttling.

This counter reflects the user override that is monitored by the engine and interpreted as follows:
* 0: No override * 1: Always throttle message delivery * 2: Do not throttle message delivery
Number of messages received by adapter
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Average latency in milliseconds from when the Messaging Engine receives a document from the adapter until the time it is published to Message Box.
Average latency in milliseconds from when the adapter gets a document from the Messaging Engine until the time it is sent by the adapter.
Average latency in milliseconds from when the Messaging Engine receives a document from the Message Box until the time document is sent by the adapter.
Average latency in milliseconds from when the Messaging Engine receives a request document from the adapter until the time a response document is given back to the adapter.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk (Message Box)

measure.description: Tracks the sum of all the instances of each host, which exist within a particular Message Box.
Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which releases database rows associated with dead BizTalk processes.
Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which cleans up message box tables associated with removed messages.
Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which clean up message box tables associated with removed message parts.

Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which purges subscriptions which are no longer in use.Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which purges subscriptions which are no longer in use.
Tracks the size of the spool on a particular message box on a particular server.
Time in seconds for most recent run of SQL agent job which copies tracked message bodies for tracked messages.
Time in seconds for the most recent run of the SQL agent job which purges the inactive tracking spool tables.
Tracks the size of the tracking data table on a particular message box on a particular server.
